Award.AwardTitle: The Perceptual Identification and Representation of Image Contours

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
It has long been recognized that a convincing pictorial representation of an object can sometimes be achieved by drawing just a few salient contours in an image. This phenomenon is really quite remarkable, given that a line drawing effectively strips away almost all of the variations in color and shading that are ordinarily available in natural scenes. Somehow the artists who create such drawings are able to capture the essential information for perceptual recognition with just a few simple strokes. Although a well structured line drawing is easily interpreted by human observers, the ability to create these drawings can require considerable artistic skill. Indeed, despite almost a half century of research in the field of computer vision, there are no existing algorithms that can duplicate the performance of a competent human artist. In this project, Dr. James Todd and his students at the Ohio State University will investigate how human observers perceptually identify different types of image contours, such as shadows, corners or occlusion. The group will also examine which contours in an image are perceptually most important for creating pictorial representations of objects. The stimuli in these studies will include drawings by artists with varying amounts of training, who will be asked to produce line drawings of objects with known 3D structures. The drawings will be ranked by human observers to assess their relative perceptual effectiveness. The contours in the drawings will also be compared with different aspects of the depicted surface geometry in order to determine which specific aspects of a surface are most important for its pictorial depiction.

A better understanding of how human observers perceptually determine the 3D shapes of surfaces from 2D image data has many possible applications, including the design of more robust and effective algorithms in machine vision, improved techniques for 3D visualization in computer graphics and design, and the potential development of more functional prosthetic devices for the blind. This work may also have a significant impact on how students are taught to draw in art or design courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research performed on this project has been designed to investigate the perception and representation of image contours at several different levels of analysis. We have performed numerous experiments to explore various aspects of this topic. The research has been organized into three general themes, which are summarized below.

One important aspect of this project concerns the perceptual analysis of surface contours and patterns of texture for the estimation of 3D shape. Several of the patterns employed in this research are shown in Figure 1. We have developed a set of context dependent models whose applicability varies with the statistical properties of the texture and the visual angle with which a surface is viewed. These models can accuratly predict the perceived shapes of surfaces over a wide range of conditions.

Another closely related aspect of our research concerns the perception of 3D shape from isointensity contours that define the pattern of shading in an image. This work has focused on the phenomenon of shape constancy over systematic variations in the pattern of illumination or material properties of a surface. For example, Figure 2 shows an object with two different directions of illumination and their resulting patterns of isointensity contours. Our research has shown that the apparent shapes of surfaces become slightly distorted by changes in illumination or material properties, but that these distortions are much smaller than what would be expected based on the overall variations in image structure. In other words, observers exhibit a high degree of shape constancy, although it is not perfect.

A third central theme of our research is to investigate the specific data structures by which objects are perceptually represented. Our working hypothesis has been that the relative perceptual salience of different object attributes are largely determined by their invariance over different types of transformations. For example, properties such as topological relations that are invariant over a wide range of transformations are judged more accurately than properties such as Euclidean relations that are only invariant over a much smaller set of transformations. Some of the stimuli employed in this research are shown in Figure 3. The results reveal that the relative perceptual salience of different types of shape change are consistent with our hypothesis. That is to say, observers are most sensitive to changes in topological structure, followed by changes in projective, affine and Euclidean structure, respectively.
